author: pipermerriam
content:
Quick check.  You guys are familiar with EIP2718 aka typed transaction envelope? (https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2718)

I'm curious how (if at all) it could benefit/simplify/improve/worsen account abstraction and if there is any reading I can do on the combined subject.

author: .vbuterin
content: Some form of transaction versioning is definitely needed for AA

author: .vbuterin
content: It's needed for lots of things

author: sky.cactus
content: I still *very weakly* argue that we can achieve many of the benefits of account abstraction with just 2718 (Typed Transactions), 2711 (Sponsored, expiring and batch transactions), and 2803 (Rich Transactions).

author: sky.cactus
content: And with, I believe, significantly less R&D work.

author: sky.cactus
content: If/when we have all 3 of those implemented, the benefits of account abstraction are pretty significantly reduced, just because we would already have many of the benefits.

author: sky.cactus
content: To the point where AA may not really make sense for ETH1x (extra time/complexity).

author: .vbuterin
content: How do any of those solutions let us do smart contract wallets without wasting an extra ECDSA signature on some intermediary?

author: sky.cactus
content: They don't let you have smart contract wallets *per say*, but they allow you to reap some of the benefits that smart wallets provide.

author: sky.cactus
content: For example, 2718 lets you do transaction batching, meaning you can do multiple calls in sequence from an EOA.

author: sky.cactus
content: And 2803 lets you execute arbitrary code from the context of an EOA (so you can do some on-chain logic prior to calling a dapp).

author: .vbuterin
content: right, I guess for me enabling smart contract wallets as a proper first-class default, with use cases like multisig, social recovery and the like, is really important. This "default pressure" toward wallets having single-key authorization policies is my #1 enemy

author: .vbuterin
content: I'm increasingly seeing the wisdom in EOS having protocol-layer smart wallets ðŸ˜† ðŸ˜†

author: sky.cactus
content: All of my assets are in a Recoverable Wallet, and it is very frustrating when I cannot interact with a dapp because they have some stupid `isHuman` check, so I definitely get the argument.  ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: One minor argument is that the above 3 combined make `isHuman` checks basically pointless because they don't give the guarantees that people are striving for with `isHuman` checks, so maybe we would see them go away?

author: .vbuterin
content: The isHuman checks are there to enforce non-transferability, right?

author: .vbuterin
content: (I just had a friend come close to losing $100,000 last week..... I had to do some digging and figure out how to manually derive a totally different BIP32 path from their seed ðŸ˜¢ )

author: .vbuterin
content: so fortunate that the problem was resolvable, still a big scare

author: sky.cactus
content: `isHuman` checks are usually there to prevent bots from bypassing really poorly designed gaming mechanisms.

author: sky.cactus
content: For example, using previous blockhash as a random number generator for a dice game, you don't want someone betting only if they will win.

author: sky.cactus
content: (trivial example, but I think it gets the point across)

author: sky.cactus
content: 2803 makes it so you can do that from an EOA with no way for the callee to know.

author: .vbuterin
content: right.... there's better solutions for that sort of stuff (basically any amount of asynchrony)

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, we have been telling people for a while that "if you have an isHuman check, then you probably are vulnerable" but they don't listen. ðŸ˜–

author: sky.cactus
content: I want to be clear, I *do* think AA is useful even with the above 3 EIPs implemented.  I just think it may not be useful *enough* to put in the dev effort on ETH1x if we have the above 3 EIPs implemented (all of which are far simpler than AA I think).

author: sky.cactus
content: I think for ETH2 AA is definitely useful and I would almost argue should be a requirement.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> right, I guess for me enabling smart contract wallets as a proper first-class default, with use cases like multisig, social recovery and the like, is really important. This "default pressure" toward wallets having single-key authorization policies is my #1 enemy
<@!273808422753796097> Do you feel the issue here is that the ecosystem isn't supporting smart wallets on their own, so core devs need to "force it"?  Or is there something about AA that makes smart wallets easier or more possible to be supported by the ecosystem?

author: sky.cactus
content: MetaMask, for example, only supports EOAs right now, but it certainly *could* support a wide variety of smart wallets I believe.

author: sky.cactus
content: (in fact, I *do* have a browser plugin that lets me use a smart wallet with dapps, it just doesn't have a UI that anyone other than I can use)

author: .vbuterin
content: I think the problem is that smart contract wallets are difficult to support right now, and so lazy wallet providers won't do it. There's a lot of "moving parts" involved: managing balances of the smart contract wallet and whatever EOA holds ETH for txfees, what if that EOA doesn't have enough funds, figuring out the interface , etc. We could yell at metamask and make them do it, but that would also further entrench metamask, which .... as *certain recently published news makes clear* has risks too

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, EOA having to pay transaction fees is a really compelling argument.

author: sky.cactus
content: It *is* annoying that my signer has to have ETH.

author: sky.cactus
content: And when it comes to asset security wallets (multisig, recoverable, social recovery, etc.) none of the aforementioned EIPs would address the problem of them being able to pay fees.

author: .vbuterin
content: there's weird edge cases too, like what if you budgeted your EOA to have $1, but then the gasprice goes up to 200 gwei and the tx costs $1.50 and [insert Carlos Matos whatamigonnado emoji here]

author: sky.cactus
content: At best you can use sponsored transactions to have *someone else* pay your fees, but not the smart wallet.

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah.  I have ETH for gas sitting on a hardware wallet that has no recovery seed.  ðŸ˜¬   It is currently the cost/risk of securing my assets.

author: sky.cactus
content: Too little and I can't pay for transactions, too much and I lose more if my hardware wallet breaks or is lost.

author: lightclient
content:
> Quick check.  You guys are familiar with EIP2718 aka typed transaction envelope? (https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2718)
> I'm curious how (if at all) it could benefit/simplify/improve/worsen account abstraction and if there is any reading I can do on the combined subject.
Yes, we're aware and are planning to utilize it. Like <@!301186049323958275> said, I think that EIP-2711 allows for a lot of functionality with very little R&D, but it still doesn't solve the root issues that AA tries to address (e.g. abstracting tx validity requirements from the protocol)
